xxl.core.predicates
Class Predicate<P>

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.predicates.Predicate<P>
Type Parameters:
P - the type of the predicate's parameters.
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable
Direct Known Subclasses:
AllPredicate, AnyPredicate, BinaryPredicate, BindingPredicate, ComparatorPredicate, ContainsPredicate, DecoratorPredicate, DefaultMemoryManageableSA.EveryQth, DimOverlapPredicate, DistanceWithin, Equal, EqualReference, EveryNth, ExistPredicate, FeaturePredicate, FunctionPredicate, GESS.ReferencePointMethod, Indicator, InputStreamEqualPredicate, MultiFeaturePredicate, NotEqual, OverlapsPredicate, Replicator.Split, UnitCubeConstraint
public abstract class Predicate<P>
extends Object
implements Serializable

This class provides a predicate, i.e. a kind of function that implements a logical statement and, when it is invoked, determines whether specified objects fulfill the statement. Predicates are highly related to functions. Like functions, predicates provide a set of invoke methods that can be used to evaluate the predicate. For providing predicates with and without parameters, this class contains invoke methods with zero, one and two arguments and with a typed list of arguments. The invoke methods call themselves in a recursive manner. That means when using the default implementation the invoke method with zero, one or two arguments calls the invoke method with a typed grep list containing the arguments and the other way round (see appropriate invoke methods). For this reason, an invoke method with the desired signatur has to be overridden in order to declare a predicate as an object of class Predicate.

But in contrast with functions, predicates do not return the result of their evaluation as an object (that must be cast to a Boolean object for getting the correct result), but as a primitive boolean value.

A first example shows how to declare a tautology, i.e. a predicate that always returns true: 

     Predicate<Object> tautology = new Predicate<Object>() {
         public boolean invoke(List<? extends Object> arguments) {
             return true;
         }
     };
In this example, the invoke method with a list of objects as argument has been overwritten. Thanks to the recursive default implementation of the invoke methods, every invoke method calls the overwritten method and the overwritten method itself breaks the recursion.

A second example shows how to declare a predicate implementing the logical statement 'n is even': 

     Predicate<Integer> even = new Predicate<Integer>() {
         public boolean invoke(Integer n) {
             return n % 2 == 0;
         }
     };
In this example, the invoke method with one argument has been overwritten. This method guarantees the specification of the parameter n that is needed for the evaluation of the predicate. Thanks to the recursive default implementation it is all the same whether the user calls even.invoke(n) or even.invoke(Arrays.asList(n)). Note that default implementations of this class are still available. Therefore a call to even.invoke() will cause an infinite recursive loop.

Constructor Detail

Predicate

public Predicate()
Sole constructor. (For invocation by subclass constructors, typically implicit.)

Method Detail

invoke

public boolean invoke(List<? extends P> arguments)
Returns the result of the predicate as a primitive boolean value. This method determines arguments.size() and calls the appropriate invoke method (see below). The other invoke methods call this method. This means, that the user either has to override this method or at least one (!) of the other invoke methods. The following listing shows the exact implementation of this method: 
     if (arguments == null)
         return invoke((P)null);
     switch (arguments.size()) {
         case 0 :
             return invoke();
         case 1 :
             return invoke(arguments.get(0));
         case 2 :
             return invoke(arguments.get(0), arguments.get(1));
         default :
             throw new RuntimeException("boolean invoke(List<? extends P> arguments) has to be overridden! The number of arguments was " + arguments.size() + ".");
     }

Parameters:
arguments - the arguments to the predicate.
Returns:
the result of the predicate as a primitive boolean value.
Throws:
RuntimeException - if an object array with length≥3 is given and the corresponding invoke method (boolean invoke (List<? extends P>)) has not been overridden.

invoke

public boolean invoke()
Returns the result of the predicate as a primitive boolean value. This method calls the invoke method working on lists with an empty list (see below). This means, that the user has to override this method to create a predicate without any argument. The following listing shows the exact implementation of this method: 
     return invoke(new ArrayList<P>(0));

Returns:
the result of the predicate as a primitive boolean value.

invoke

public boolean invoke(P argument)
Returns the result of the predicate as a primitive boolean value. This method calls the invoke method working on lists with a list containing the given argument (see below). This means, that the user has to override this method to create a predicate with one argument. The following listing shows the exact implementation of this method: 
     return invoke(Arrays.asList(argument));

Parameters:
argument - the argument to the predicate.
Returns:
the result of the predicate as a primitive boolean value.

invoke

public boolean invoke(P argument0,
                      P argument1)
Returns the result of the predicate as a primitive boolean value. This method calls the invoke method working on lists with a list containing the given arguments (see below). This means, that the user has to override this method to create a predicate with two arguments. The following listing shows the exact implementation of this method: 
     return invoke(Arrays.asList(argument0, argument1));

Parameters:
argument0 - the first argument to the predicate.
argument1 - the second argument to the predicate.
Returns:
the result of the predicate as a primitive boolean value.

main

public static void main(String[] args)
The main method contains some examples how to use a Predicate. It can also be used to test the functionality of a Predicate.

Parameters:
args - array of String arguments. It can be used to submit parameters when the main method is called.
